conclusion: The light source casts shadows (A, B, C, D) behind the objects onto the ground, indicating the light source is behind and slightly above the objects.
When the light source moves forward, it shifts closer to the objects while also moving slightly above them.
As the light source moves closer to the objects, the shadows cast by the objects will generally become smaller due to the angle between the light rays and the objects becoming more acute.

Moving the light source forward means the shadows will shift from being cast behind the objects to potentially being cast directly under or slightly in front of the objects, depending on the light source's new position.
Shadow A, initially behind the shoe-like object, will move closer to the object and might appear underneath it as the light source moves forward.
Shadow B, initially behind the typewriter-like object, will shift toward being directly underneath it as the light source moves forward.
Shadow C, initially behind the shell-like object, will move from behind to underneath the object due to the new light source position.
Shadow D, initially behind the peach-like object, will shift from being cast behind it to possibly being cast underneath or slightly in front, depending on the light source's new position.

When the light source moves forward and above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller and shift their positions from being cast behind the objects to being cast directly underneath or slightly in front of the objects.
